title: Rclone tries to resolve symlinks even though they are stated in an exclude filter
body:
#### Associated forum post
There is a related [forum post](https://forum.rclone.org/t/symbolic-link-stat-error-on-excluded-file-result-in-i-o-error/23539)


#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
When rclone is called with the `-L` or `--copy-links` flag it tries to resolve symlinks even though they are stated in an exclude filter. I would expect rclone to ignore the symlinks when they are stated in a filter. It looks like rclone first tries to resolve the links and only afterwards applies the filter. This is also stated by @ncw in the related forum post. I didn't find any related issue to the post by Tercio Filho therefore opening this one.

**Steps to reproduce**
1. Creating a broken symlink
```
touch file1
touch file2
ln -s file1 link1
ln -s file2 link2
rm file 1  # to break link1
```
2. Afterwards although specifically excluded by the filter the broken symlink still results in an Error
```
$ rclone ls -L . --exclude link1 -vv
2022/08/11 10:07:11 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.53.3-DEV" starting with parameters ["rclone" "ls" "-L" "." "--exclude" "link1" "-vv"]
2022/08/11 10:07:11 DEBUG : Creating backend with remote "."
2022/08/11 10:07:11 NOTICE: Config file "/home/rothe/.config/rclone/rclone.conf" not found - using defaults
2022/08/11 10:07:11 DEBUG : fs cache: renaming cache item "." to be canonical "/tmp/rclone"
2022/08/11 10:07:11 ERROR : link1: Listing error: symlink: stat /tmp/rclone/link1: no such file or directory
        0 file2
        0 link2
2022/08/11 10:07:11 DEBUG : 2 go routines active
2022/08/11 10:07:11 Failed to ls: symlink: stat /tmp/rclone/link1: no such file or directory
```
exit status is 6


#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
```
rclone version
rclone v1.53.3-DEV
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.18.1
```


#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (e.g. Windows 7, 64 bit)
Debian 5.18.14-1 (2022-07-23) x86_64


#### Which cloud storage system are you using? (e.g. Google Drive)
None, this is reproducible locally with `rclone ls`
